  • Method Details

    • encode

      public <T> String encode(T obj, String secondaryKey, long tokenExpirationTime) throws JwtKnowyException
      Encodes the given object into a signed JWT string.

      This method serializes the provided object and places it under the "data" claim in the JWT payload. The token is then signed using a derived secret key, which is calculated by combining:

      • The user's encrypted password (used as a user-specific secret), and
      • A secure server-side secret key unique to the application environment.
      This design ensures that the token is cryptographically bound to both the user and the server, offering strong protection against forgery even if one secret is compromised.

      The caller can specify a custom expiration time (in milliseconds), after which the token will be invalid.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the object being encoded
      Parameters:
      obj - the object to encode into the JWT payload, typically including security-relevant data (e.g., user ID, email, token type)
      secondaryKey - a user-specific component (usually the encrypted password) used to derive the signing key
      tokenExpirationTime - the expiration time in milliseconds (e.g., 600_000 for 10 minutes, 3_600_000 for 1 hour)
      Returns:
      a compact JWT string containing the signed and encoded data
      Throws:
      JwtKnowyException - if token generation fails due to signing or serialization issues

    • encode

      public <T> String encode(T obj, String secondaryKey) throws JwtKnowyException
      Encodes the given object into a signed JWT string with a default expiration time of 10 minutes (600,000 ms).

      This method is a convenience overload of encode(Object, String, long), which uses a fixed expiration duration of 10 minutes. It signs the token using a key derived from a combination of:

      • The user's encrypted password (as a user-specific secret), and
      • A server-side secret unique to the application environment.
      This ensures the token is cryptographically bound to both the user and the server.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the object being encoded
      Parameters:
      obj - the object to encode into the JWT payload (e.g., user ID, email, token type)
      secondaryKey - a user-specific component (typically an encrypted password) used to derive the signing key
      Returns:
      a compact, signed JWT string containing the encoded data
      Throws:
      JwtKnowyException - if token generation fails due to signing or serialization issues

    • decode

      public <T> T decode(String secondaryKey, String token, Class<T> clazz) throws JwtKnowyException
      Decodes and verifies a signed JWT token using a dynamically derived HMAC key, and deserializes the "data" claim into an instance of the specified class.

      The verification key (superkey) is derived by applying HMAC-SHA256 to the provided secondaryKey (e.g., the user’s encrypted password), using a server-side base secret key. This ensures that:

      • The token is tied both to the user and the server environment.
      • It cannot be verified or regenerated without both keys being correct.

      After verifying the token's signature, this method extracts the "data" field from the payload and deserializes it into the specified class.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the deserialized object
      Parameters:
      secondaryKey - the user-specific secondary key used to derive the HMAC verification key
      token - the signed JWT token to decode and verify
      clazz - the class to deserialize the "data" claim into
      Returns:
      the deserialized object from the "data" claim
      Throws:
      JwtKnowyException - if the token is invalid, the signature cannot be verified, or deserialization fails

    • decodeUnverified

      public <T> T decodeUnverified(String token, Class<T> clazz) throws JwtKnowyException
      Decodes a JWT token *without verifying its signature* and extracts the "data" claim from the payload, mapping it to an instance of the specified class.

      ⚠️ Warning: This method does not verify the JWT's signature. Use it only in trusted environments or when the token has already been verified through other means.

      The method expects the JWT payload to be a JSON object that includes a top-level "data" field, which itself is a JSON object representing the domain-specific content.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type to deserialize the "data" object into
      Parameters:
      token - the JWT token string (Base64-encoded header.payload.signature)
      clazz - the target class to map the "data" field to
      Returns:
      an instance of the specified class representing the "data" claim
      Throws:
      JwtKnowyException - if the token is invalid, improperly formatted, or if deserialization of the "data" field fails
